history.content:
You can check out a previous QC course taught by Vazirani here: https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~vazirani/f16quantum.html.

In general, you should probably have a good knowledge of linear algebra (of the level of Math 110), algorithms (CS 170), and physics (Physics 137A) to really get the most out of this class. The one out of these three that is most necessary is CS 170, since you need that knowledge to prove things about the complexity of quantum algorithms (otherwise you will be very lost). The math/physics can be built up or supplemented if you really only care about the computation side of things. If you want to get a head start on the material, the standard textbook is Quantum Computation and Quantum Information by Nielsen and Chuang. You can also check out Nielsen's youtube lectures if you are so inclined.

This fall Prof. Vazirani is going to be teaching a course about Quantum Computing. I have very little background in this topic (I did a week in CS170 last semester I guess), but I really want to take this class if it is taught by him. I was wondering about what sort of material I should be expecting and whether I would be completely out of my depth in this class.
history.subject: CS294-66 Material/Pre-Requisites/Information
